results.title: Daintree: The Vanishing Rainforest
results.creator_credit: Danae Gunn, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This video is Part 5 in a series of 6 documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. A child returns from the future, a time when forests no longer exist and we see the rainforest and its most unusual inhabitants through her eyes. She grows to love the forest and cannot understand some of the things she sees happening. This is an imaginative and fascinating story which emphasises the delicate balance of nature, and how easily it can be destroyed. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Danae Gunn, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)

results.title: South West Tasmania: The Gliders
results.creator_credit: Catherine Millar, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
The sheer challenge of remote wilderness is shown in this spectacular program which is Part 4 in a series of 6 documentaries, of a group’s arduous trek to Federation Peak with the aim of hang gliding from the summit. Young and old participate in the trek and viewers share the thoughts, inspiration and differing goals of the group.

results.title: The Aviators of Hudson Strait
results.creator_credit: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at early Canadian aviation, through film footage shot by the Royal Canadian Air Force and the recollections of retired Air Vice-Marshal Thomas A. Lawrence, leader of the 1927-28 aerial survey expedition to Ungava Bay and Hudson Strait. The formidable challenge of flying under Arctic conditions, the hazards faced and the emergencies solved, often with the help of Inuit, make an absorbing chapter of northern frontier history. Written by William Weintraub.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Weintraub and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Backbone of life
results.creator_credit: John Gauci, Gus Mercurio and Gus Mercurio Enterprises
results.brief_description: Gus Mercurio has been a Registered Doctor of Chiropractic for over 35 years. These routines have enriched his own life and can do the same for you. The whole routine in 2 parts takes less than 40 minutes to complete and can be easily adapted to your day. Designed for the mature, it includes stretching and toning, low impact aerobics - walking, swimming or cycling - weight training and isometrics and relaxation. Proper sleep support and dietary advice are covered to make this tape a must for any-one suffering muscular or back discomfort.

results.title: Kakadu: Land of the Crocodile
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Wilderness is increasingly recognised as a scarce and vital commodity worldwide. In this video, Part 2 in a series of 6 documentaries, Val Plumwood, environmental philosopher and writer returns to Kakadu, where she was the victim of a terrible crocodile attack. Set against the steamy, intensely beautiful, backdrop of Kakadu National Park viewers share her thoughts on wilderness and wildlife. Accompanied by a Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Central Australia: tracks in the sand
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures, when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson. Accompanied by a Teacher’s guide.

results.title: Central Australia: tracks in the sand (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Cartoonist Michael Leunig records his impressions of Alice Springs, Ayers Rock and the vast emptiness of the Simpson Desert. Viewers are privy to a special meeting of minds and cultures when he shares a canvas on the sand with Aboriginal artist, Michael Nelson.
